metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

title.gco:CharacterString: A chart of the Indian Ocean improved from the chart of M. d'Apres de Mannevillette; with the addition of a part of the Pacific Ocean, as well as of the original tracks of the principal discoverers or other navigators to India and China; and in which it has been attempted to give a chronological indication of the successive discoveries (Raster Image)

alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: A chart of the Indian Ocean improved from the chart of M. d'Apres de Mannevillette; with the addition of a part of the Pacific Ocean, as well as of the original tracks of the principal discoverers or other navigators to India and China; and in which it has been attempted to give a chronological indication of the successive discoveries

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This layer is a georeferenced raster image of the historic paper map of the Indian Ocean. The original map was originally created by Louis Delarochette and published in 1803. This map shows the entire continent of Africa. Additional areas displayed in this map include: the Pacific Ocean, Australia, and part of Asia. The features illustrated on this map includes: lakes, coastal islands, gulfs, seas. There are 2 inset maps titled, North East Monsoon, South West Monsoon. All map collar and inset information is also available as part of the raster image, including any inset maps, profiles, statistical tables, directories, text, illustrations, or other information associated with the principal map. The map was georeferenced by the Stanford Geospatial Center using a Mercator projection. This map is part of a selection of digitally scanned and georeferenced historic maps of Africa held at Stanford University Libraries

purpose.gco:CharacterString: This historic paper map provides an historical perspective of the cultural and physical landscape during this time period. The wide range of information provided on these maps make them useful in the study of historic geography. As this map has been georeferenced, it also can be used as a background layer in conjunction with other GIS data.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Delarochette, Louis and Stanford Geospatial Center. (2013). A chart of the Indian Ocean improved from the chart of M. d'Apres de Mannevillette; with the addition of a part of the Pacific Ocean, as well as of the original tracks of the principal discoverers or other navigators to India and China; and in which it has been attempted to give a chronological indication of the successive discoveries (Raster Image). Stanford Digital Repository. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/mq457xb3818.

useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: This item is in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Creative Commons Public Domain Mark 1.0.

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Images may be reproduced or transmitted, but not for commercial use.” For commercial use or commercial republication, contact brannerlibrary@stanford.edu. Attribution-Non Commercial: CC BY-NC."

supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: For more information about Stanford's Maps of Africa Collection, see here: https://exhibits.stanford.edu/maps-of-africa.

gml:UnitDefinition.gml:identifier: Unified Code of Units of Measure

evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: The georeferenced raster is a faithfully reproduced digital image of the original source map. Some differences may be detected between the source graphic used and the raster image due to the RGB values assigned that particular color. The intent is to recreate those colors as near as possible.

The horizontal positional accuracy of a raster image is approximately the same as the accuracy of the published source map. The lack of a greater accuracy is largely the result of the inaccuracies with the original measurements and possible distortions in the original paper map document. There may also be errors introduced during the digitizing and georeferencing process. In most cases, however, errors in the raster image are small compared with sources of error in the original map graphic. The RMS error for this map is 1899.6 meters. This value describes how consistent the transformation is between the different control points (links). The RMS error is only an assessment of the accuracy of the transformation.
Data completeness for raster digital image files reflect content of the source graphic. Features may have been eliminated or generalized on the source graphic due to scale and legibility constraints.

statement.gco:CharacterString: This map was scanned and georeferenced by the Stanford University Geospatial Center using a Mercator projection. The prime meridian used during the georeferencing process was the Greenwich prime meridian and the central meridian was set at 0, the latitude of origin used for all regional maps was 0°. In the process of georeferencing this map, 4 control points were created. The transformation order used to georeference the map is 1st order.

description.gco:CharacterString: The following spatially referenced data was used during the georeferencing process; it was used for verification purposes: 1) Natural Earth: 1, 5, 15 and 20 degree vector graticules. 2) Natural Earth: 10 meter vector coastline Made with Natural Earth. Free vector and raster map data @ naturalearthdata.com

title.gco:CharacterString: A chart of the Indian Ocean
